body_text.text: Access to global information through the Internet has become a virtual prerequisite for the practice of travel medicine. An enormous amount of information has been posted to the Internet or World Wide Web (WWW or simply the ‘web’). It is important to target official and professional sites, which provide reasonably accurate and up-to-date information. The information may assist in developing an information portfolio that will empower the practitioner to better target the health advice and interventions that they provide for the traveler. Some sites also have useful information that the practitioner can provide to the traveler, such as fact sheets. In this report, an annotated list of selected official and professional international websites is provided, together with a small selection of other national websites that may be of value as a starting point for the travel health practitioner.
body_text.section: Introduction
International Society of Travel Medicine (ISTM) ::: Websites reviewed

body_text.text: For the travel health practitioner, the website of the International Society of Travel Medicine (ISTM) is a useful starting point (see Fig. 1). With more than 1800 members in over 50 countries, it is a very large professional network of doctors, nurses and other professionals working in travel medicine, together with a number of useful initiatives for the travel health practitioner. It has a links page to a small number of other websites, including a number of North American sites reflecting a major source of its membership. A number of features and benefits are available only to ISTM members.
body_text.section: International Society of Travel Medicine (ISTM) ::: Websites reviewed

body_text.text:
Important features are links to:•Various ISTM endorsed conferences, including their biennial global meeting•Information on the ISTM Certificate of Knowledge examination•A Directory of Travel Health Providers
•The Journal of Travel Medicine
•Summary of disease outbreak news from various sources•Several institutions offering courses and training in travel medicine•GeoSentinal, a collaborative ISTM initiative for surveillance and monitoring of global trends in travel-related diseases•ISTM Listserv-TravelMed

body_text.text: Published by BC Decker, the Journal of Travel Medicine is an indexed journal dedicated to travel and migrant medicine. It was first published in 1994 and is now its 10th year of publication. This journal publishes editorials, reviews, original research, book reviews and notes from the recent literature. Abstracts are available on line to January 2001. Thereafter, there is a link to BC Decker to the full text of the journal for a limited period.
body_text.section: International Society of Travel Medicine (ISTM) ::: Websites reviewed
International Society of Travel Medicine (ISTM) ::: Websites reviewed
International Society of Travel Medicine (ISTM) ::: Websites reviewed

body_text.text: For ISTM members, this is a useful electronic means of regularly interacting with other ISTM members around the World via email. Although it is stated to be an unmoderated discussion group, it can be a useful network to source information as well as practical solutions to problems faced in travel medicine. Subscription as an ISTM member is a prerequisite for participation. For full-time and other actively involved travel health practitioners, it is probably useful to belong to an email-based discussion group.
body_text.section: International Society of Travel Medicine (ISTM) ::: Websites reviewed
World Health Organization (WHO) ::: Websites reviewed

body_text.text: The World Health Organization (WHO) website is probably the leading source of international health information and publications (see Fig. 2). It is a very large site and has some useful disease prevalence and distribution information, as well as some of the latest developments in areas such as drug resistance. There is also a very useful link on the home page dealing with the latest news on disease outbreaks and it is possible to look through archived news as well. While not all information is directly relevant to travel medicine, it does have a link to a dedicated site for travel medicine.
body_text.section: World Health Organization (WHO) ::: Websites reviewed
World Health Organization (WHO) ::: Websites reviewed
World Health Organization (WHO) ::: Websites reviewed

body_text.text: For many years, the WHO has published guidelines for travel health titled International Travel and Health.1 In recent years, these have been annually updated and more recently they have also been available on the Internet (see Fig. 3). Previously referred as the ‘yellow’ book by the color of its cover, it is the ‘blue’ book, reflecting a change in the color of its cover. This publication is a useful adjunct to national guidelines on travel health, where these are available. It has a very useful country-by-country guide, which includes basic information such as the capitol city, elevation, vaccination requirements with special reference to yellow fever vaccination, and the general situation with respect to malaria. A useful editorial on the development of these guidelines is given elsewhere.2
body_text.section: World Health Organization (WHO) ::: Websites reviewed

World Health Organization (WHO) ::: Websites reviewed

body_text.text: The Weekly Epidemiological Record (WER) is an indexed public health journal, which is published weekly. It provided for rapid dissemination of ‘epidemiological information on cases and outbreaks of diseases under the International Health Regulations and on other communicable diseases of public health importance, including the newly emerging or re-emerging infections’ (see Fig. 4).
body_text.section: World Health Organization (WHO) ::: Websites reviewed

body_text.text: WHO Bulletin of the World Health Organization
body_text.section: World Health Organization (WHO) ::: Websites reviewed
World Health Organization (WHO) ::: Websites reviewed

body_text.text: The Bulletin of the World Health Organization is an indexed public health journal, which has become available on line in recent years. It covers various topical public health and policy issues. Archives are available on line back to 1996.
body_text.section: World Health Organization (WHO) ::: Websites reviewed
Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), Atlanta, USA ::: Websites reviewed

body_text.text: Although not primarily an international website, it is an official site of the US Government frequently linked from many other official sites around the world. Like the WHO, the CDC has a very large website and is also a leading source of international health information and publications. It has some useful disease prevalence and distribution information. There is also a very useful link on the home page dealing with the latest news on disease outbreaks and it is possible to look through some archived news as well. There is a very useful A–Z section, which includes fact sheets on various diseases. While not all information is directly relevant to travel medicine, it does have a link to a dedicated site for travel medicine.
body_text.section: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), Atlanta, USA ::: Websites reviewed
Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), Atlanta, USA ::: Websites reviewed
Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), Atlanta, USA ::: Websites reviewed

body_text.text: For many years, the CDC has published guidelines on travel health titled Health Information for International Travel.3 In recent years, these have been updated biannually and more recently have become available online (see Fig. 5). These guidelines are referred to now as the yellow book, reflecting the color of its cover. It is a comprehensive book of guidelines on travel health for the USA. Some special features include ‘build custom report’ feature, which allows the compilation of travel health information from the guidelines database on yellow fever vaccine requirements, malaria, and potential health risks. This could be very useful information globally, if the information is managed in the context of national guidelines for travel health for various countries.
body_text.section: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), Atlanta, USA ::: Websites reviewed

body_text.text: CDC Cruise Ships and Air Travel
body_text.section: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), Atlanta, USA ::: Websites reviewed
Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), Atlanta, USA ::: Websites reviewed

body_text.text: An interesting section of the travelers health website is the section on cruise ships and air travel. The cruise ship section includes sanitation inspections for all cruise ships berthing in the USA. The air travel section also provides useful links to topical issues such as Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome (SARS).
body_text.section: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), Atlanta, USA ::: Websites reviewed

body_text.text: CDC Morbidity and Mortality Weekly Report
body_text.section: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), Atlanta, USA ::: Websites reviewed
Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), Atlanta, USA ::: Websites reviewed

body_text.text: The Morbidity and Mortality Weekly Report is an indexed public health journal, which is published weekly. Like the Weekly Epidemiological Record, it focuses on disease outbreaks and health concerns, but with a special emphasis on the USA. There have been some very useful reviews of travelers' health related issues.

Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), Atlanta, USA ::: Websites reviewed
Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), Atlanta, USA ::: Websites reviewed

body_text.text: Emerging Infectious Diseases is a peer-reviewed and indexed public health journal, which is published monthly. It aims to track and analyze disease trends with a view to providing information on emerging infectious diseases. Established in 1995, all issues of the journal are available online.
body_text.section: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), Atlanta, USA ::: Websites reviewed
International Association for Medical Assistance to Travellers (IAMAT) ::: Websites reviewed

body_text.text: International Association for Medical Assistance to Travellers (IAMAT), a well known not for profit organization, was founded in 1960 and maintains a network of travel health practitioners and clinics globally. Individual travelers can also join IAMAT. It has a number of resources of disease and geographical medicine issues available at its website, but some benefits are limited to members (see Fig. 6).
body_text.section: International Association for Medical Assistance to Travellers (IAMAT) ::: Websites reviewed
International Society for Infectious Diseases Promed-mail ::: Websites reviewed

body_text.text: This is another useful networking and listserv resource and information source on emerging infectious disease. It is available in several languages. Participation in this email based discussion group is by subscription. A useful review of other national and international organizational websites has been published elsewhere.4
body_text.section: International Society for Infectious Diseases Promed-mail ::: Websites reviewed

body_text.text: This is a literature search engine for all journals indexed by PubMed. It can be a useful means of finding published literature on travel medicine subjects. Abstracts are available for most recent journal articles and links are provided where available to online journals. Many of these online journals require subscription.

body_text.text: The Cochrane Collaboration published and indexed systematic reviews on various healthcare interventions. A number of these relate to travel medicine. Abstracts are available online. In some countries, the full text may also be available online.
body_text.section: Literature searches/sources ::: Websites reviewed
Elsevier's, Travel Medicine and Infectious Disease ::: Websites reviewed

body_text.text: Elsevier commenced publication of a new peer-reviewed journal, Travel Medicine and Infectious Disease, which is currently indexed on Science Direct. The full text of the first issue is currently available as complimentary through ScienceDirect.
